page.title: 15Chickney, goodwill attitudes
page.content: Some opposition toi project but attitudes mostly very co-operative especially from those of long Essex family history. Some farmers resent walkers and horseriders on their land. Established bridle and footpaths give public right of way but this is sometimes abused; crops damaged, gates left open, animals straying into danger and even causing road accidents. Thus, as there is no trespass law, the farmer has no re-dress. Another aspect fof the problem which reacts against the public's rights, is deliberate acts of vandalism whereby signposts have been removed resulting in the ploughing up of unmarked paths by farmers. Efforts are being made to promote goodwill by educating the public to cooperate with the farmer.In small residential groups a good community spirit prevails.
